|Title=Know the definition of pregestational diabetes (vs gestational diabetes)
|Description=None
|Rubric=Definition
|Contributors=Eva Feigerlova,Hélène Bihan,Claire Briet,Etienne Larger,Gaetan Prevost
|Order=5}}

Pre-pregnancy diabetes is defined as the presence of diabetes prior to pregnancy.

Pre-pregnancy diabetes includes type 1 and type 2 diabetes, which by definition are present before pregnancy.

Gestational diabetes is defined as glucose intolerance that becomes apparent and/or develops during pregnancy. It is diagnosed using an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) between the 24<sup>th</sup> and 28<sup>th</sup> week of pregnancy. [[Gestational diabetes]]

<ref>Polycopy of the College of Teachers of Endocrinology, Diabetes and Metabolic Diseases (4th edition, 2019)</ref>
<references />

question.question: What is the defining characteristic of pre-pregnancy diabetes?
question.option_a: It is diagnosed using an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) between the 24th and 28th week of pregnancy.
question.option_b: It is a form of diabetes that develops only during pregnancy.
question.option_c: It includes type 1 and type 2 diabetes, which are present before pregnancy.
question.option_d: It is a condition that affects only the mother and not the fetus.
